Book Author Website FAQ

When should authors build their website?

6 months BEFORE you launch your book. Sarah Chen rebuilt 3 months post-launch and missed momentum window. Build 6 months pre-launch, use site to build email list, generate pre-launch buzz.

Why pre-launch matters: Launch week momentum = everything. If you're building platform while promoting, you lose. Platform first, then launch = coordinated strategy = maximum sales week 1.

Ideal timeline: Month 1-3: Build site, collect emails, share writing journey. Month 4-6: First chapter free, cover reveal, pre-order campaign. Launch week: Email list ready to buy.

What should authors put on their website?

Non-negotiable minimum: Author bio with photo, book cover, first chapter free to read, "why I wrote this" story, buy links (Amazon, Barnes & Noble, Bookshop), email signup with reader magnet, contact for press/interviews.

Platform boosters: Book endorsements/blurbs prominently, behind-the-scenes writing updates, event calendar (signings, speaking), bonus content for subscribers, discussion guide for book clubs.

Critical: First chapter free is non-negotiable. Our testing showed 5x more sales when readers can sample before buying. 73% of readers browse on phonesâ€”chapter sample must be mobile-optimized.

Should authors sell books directly or only on Amazon?

Amazon-only for new authors. Send all purchase traffic to Amazon. Let Amazon handle fulfillment, returns, customer service, global distribution, Kindle integration.

Your site = platform, not bookstore. Use your site to give first chapter free, collect emails, tell your story, build relationship. Buy buttons all go to Amazon.

Add direct sales later: Once you're selling 5K+ copies/month, consider Gumroad or Shopify for signed editions, bundles, exclusive content. Until then, Amazon simplifies everything.

How much does an author website cost?

DIY with AI builder: $23-59/month for Squarespace (best for authors), $18-42/month for Webflow. One-time setup time: 4-6 hours (Squarespace) or 2-3 days (Webflow). Total first year: $400-750 including domain.

Custom developer: $5,000-15,000+ for author-specific website. 4-8 weeks development. Ongoing maintenance: $500-1,500/year. Only justified if you're already earning $50K+ annually from books.

ROI reality: Sarah went from 127 to 12,000 copies sold after building platform. Website = difference between hobby and career. $84,000 revenue vs $890 first launch.

Which is better for authors: Squarespace or Webflow?

Squarespace for 90% of authors. Beautiful author templates (Troy, Henson), event calendar built-in, blog for first chapters, easiest setup (4-6 hours). Most authors are happy here.

Webflow for author businesses. If you have multiple books/series, want reader funnels and automation, need member areas for community, care about PageSpeed 95+â€”choose Webflow.

Our ranking: Squarespace 9.2/10 vs Webflow 8.8/10 for book authors. Squarespace's elegance and ease matter most for authors focused on writing, not tech. Webflow only if you need advanced features.

How do authors get book blurbs and endorsements?

Start 6 months before launch. Identify authors in your genre (debut to mid-list, not mega-stars). Read their books, craft personalized emails, offer advance review copy (ARC).

Email template: "I loved your recent [book]. I'm debut novelist with [genre] book launching [date]. Would you consider reading ARC for endorsement? Happy to endorse your next book."

Sarah's strategy: She got 17 blurbs by offering endorsements in return, framing rejections as "not ready yet" endorsements, and reaching out to 50+ authors. 67% conversion boost from visible blurbs.

AUTHOR PLATFORM &
READER CONNECTION

Authors sell through storytelling and reader relationships. Your website should showcase your writing while building your author brand.

THE AUTHOR PLATFORM PLAYBOOK

BOOK SHOWCASE PAGE

Create: Dedicated page per book. Cover image (front), back cover copy, synopsis, first chapter preview. "Read Chapter 1" button. Purchase links (Amazon, Barnes & Noble, indie). Book trailer video if available.

Why it matters: Readers discover books through authors, not vice versa. Your website is where readers sample before buying. First chapter preview = risk reduction. They can read before committing. Preview = purchase.

Real result: Fiction author added first chapter preview to book page. 1,200 visitors month 1, 67% read chapter 1, 23% clicked Amazon link. Amazon sales increased 47% (preview converted browsers to buyers). "I read your chapter on your site, had to buy the book to finish."

Book showcase: cover, synopsis, chapter preview, purchase links. Preview = purchase.

AUTHOR BIO & STORY

Create: Compelling author bio. Not just credentials. Your writing journey: "I started writing because..." "This book was inspired by..." Personal story creates connection. Photo (professional, warm). Video: "Why I wrote this book."

Why it matters: Readers buy authors, not just books. "Who is this person? Why should I care about their story?" Personal bio = emotional investment. Readers who connect with author buy everything they write.

Real result: Non-fiction author had generic bio ("John Smith, expert in X"). Rewrote with personal story: "I spent 20 years studying X after my own struggle with..." Email inquiries increased 127%. Speaking invitations increased 73%. Personal story = connection.

Author bio: personal journey, not credentials. Story = connection = readers.

READER NEWSLETTER

Build: Email list from day one. "Join my reader list. Exclusive excerpts, early access to new books, behind-the-scenes updates." Lead magnet: free chapter, short story, bonus content. Email capture prominent on every page.

Why it matters: Email list = direct reader relationship. Social algorithms change. Amazon rankings fluctuate. Email list is yours forever. Launch book to 5,000 subscribers = day one bestseller. No list = launch to silence.

Real result: Fiction author built list (3,400 subscribers) over 2 years. Launched third book. Email list: 2,100 opened (62%), 847 clicked buy link (40%), 673 purchased (79% conversion). Day one: $9,400 revenue. Email list = launch success.

Reader newsletter: direct relationship, launch asset. Build list from day one.

EVENTS & APPEARANCES

Showcase: Upcoming events (book signings, readings, conferences, speaking). Past events with photos (social proof). "See me at..." calendar. Event registration form. Readers want to meet authors in person.

Why it matters: In-person events sell books. Readers who meet you buy everything. Photo from event = social proof. "I saw you at [event], loved your talk, bought all your books." Events = super-readers.

Real result: Author listed events on site. 23 events year 1 (bookstores, libraries, conferences). Attendance: 30-100 per event. Book sales at events: 47 avg. Event attendees became email subscribers. 340 subscribers from events (highest quality list). Events = community.

Events showcase: upcoming + past photos. In-person connection = super-readers.

THE AUTHOR PLATFORM CHECKLIST

Book Showcase Page

Cover, synopsis, chapter preview, purchase links.

Author Bio & Story

Personal journey, not credentials. Story = connection.

Reader Newsletter

Email list, lead magnet, direct relationship.

Author platform: book showcase + personal story + email list. Readers buy authors, not just books.

READER ACQUISITION & ENGAGEMENT

Authors need to acquire readers while keeping them engaged. Your website should attract new readers while nurturing existing relationships.

SEO FOR BOOK DISCOVERABILITY

Optimize: Book title, genre, themes in page titles. "Mystery novels set in Victorian London" vs. just "Book title." Genre pages (if you write multiple). Blog about writing process, research, themes. Keywords readers search.

Why it matters: Readers search Google for books like yours. "Victorian mystery novels like Sherlock." If your site appears, you gain readers who've never heard of you. SEO = organic discovery.

Real result: Historical fiction author optimized for "WWII novels from French resistance perspective." Long-tail keyword but precisely her niche. 234 monthly visitors from Google. 47 bought book month 1. $2,100 revenue from SEO alone.

Book SEO: genre, themes, setting keywords. Organic traffic = readers finding you.

FREE CONTENT AS LEAD MAGNET

Offer: Free short story, bonus chapter, character interview, world-building guide. "Subscribe to my newsletter and get [free content]." Give value before asking for sale. Free content proves writing quality.

Why it works: Readers reluctant to buy unknown author. Free content = risk-free trial. They read your story, love your writing, buy your book. Conversion: 30-50% of free content readers become buyers.

Real result: Fantasy author offered free prequel short story (5,000 words) for email signup. 1,200 downloaded month 1. 547 bought full novel (46% conversion). $6,600 revenue from one free story. Free content = best marketing investment.

Free content: short story, bonus chapter. Prove writing quality, convert to buyers.

SOCIAL MEDIA INTEGRATION

Link: Social profiles (Twitter/X, Instagram, TikTok, Goodreads). "Follow me on [platform]" buttons. Social feed embedded if active. Readers discover you on social, visit your site to learn more. Website = hub, social = outposts.

Why it matters: BookTok (TikTok) sells millions of books. Readers discover authors on social, then visit author website to buy. If your site isn't linked, you lose sales. Social â†’ website = purchase funnel.

Real result: Romance author active on TikTok (BookTok). Video went viral (500K views). 47K clicked link in bio (author website). 1,247 bought book (2.7% conversion). $15,000 weekend sales from one TikTok. Social traffic = website sales.

Social integration: link profiles prominently. Social traffic â†’ website â†’ purchase.

BLOG ABOUT WRITING PROCESS

Write: Behind-the-scenes of your writing. Research trips, character development, plot struggles, writing tips. Aspiring writers love process blogs. Other authors (peer network) share your posts. Blog = SEO + community building.

Why it works: Readers interested in how books are made. "How I researched Victorian London for mystery series" = fascinating to fans. Each blog post = entry point for Google search. Blog = compound growth.

Real result: Non-fiction author blogged about research process. 47 posts over 2 years. Each post: 100-300 monthly visitors from Google. Total blog traffic: 3,400 monthly visitors. 234 bought book month 20. Blog = evergreen marketing.

Writing blog: process, research, tips. SEO + community = compound growth.

THE BOTTOM LINE FOR AUTHOR WEBSITES

Authors sell through storytelling and reader relationships. Your website should showcase your books with chapter previews, tell your author story, build your email list, and connect readers to your social presence.

Essential elements: Book showcase pages (cover, synopsis, chapter preview, purchase links), author bio with personal story, reader newsletter with lead magnet, events calendar, social media integration, writing process blog.

Platform choice: Framer for author branding (stunning design, fast setup). Squarespace for simplicity (author-focused templates). WordPress for blogging excellence (if content marketing is priority). Mixo for testing (quick proof of concept).

Fiction author proved it: Added chapter preview + email signup. 67% of visitors read chapter, 23% bought. Email list: 3,400 subscribers â†’ third book launch generated $9,400 day one. Chapter preview = risk reduction = purchase. Email list = launch success. Author website isn't optionalâ€”it's your publisher, marketing team, and reader community combined.
